title: Why The US Needs Nuclear Energy | Jordan Bramble, CEO of Antares

Yeah. So, a heat pipe um they were
actually invented in the in I want to
say 1958 u maybe it was the early '60s
but um they were actually invented at
Los Alamos National Lab specifically for
space nuclear. So, the idea is uh it's a
pipe with a vapor chamber and then in
the in the inner lining of the pipe
there's um like a wick structure and um
there's a working fluid in it. So, in
our case it's sodium. reactor heats up,
sodium vaporizes, which causes it to
travel down the pipe and um move heat as
it does. So when it gets to the cool end
of the pipe, it condenses again and um
capillary forces, so surface tension in
the wick actually brings it back. And
that cycle just repeats uh and the pipe
gets to one consistent temperature and
you're just relying on phase change to
move heat. So there's no pumping. Um
there's kind of no active mechanism to
do that. It's like a fascinatingly
simple technology, yet the physics is is
complicated. And um the other thing I
think is really cool is despite being
invented for space nuclear, there's heat
there's copper water heat pipes in your
laptop. They're in our smartphone. Like
it's like a ubiquitous technology. Um uh
heat pipes are being used in radiators
on satellites in space. Um you know,
it's kind of started from nuclear and
then branched out into many different
applications. Um, but another thing that
we really like about it is, you know, we
build them ourselves and test them
ourselves and it's fast and iterative.
It's it's very unlike, you know, going
out and having to design a new turbo
pump every time you want to change
something in your design. So, um, it
allows us to iterate much faster on

larger sizes. And so you typically want
to move to another another coolant. So
different reactor designs have a

we can actually pair these systems up
